SO = E(ST) / (1 + Rf + risk premium)T + PV (benefits of holding the asset for time
T) – PV (costs of holding the asset for time T),
where:
Sy is the current spot price of the asset and E(ST) is the expected value of the asset at
time T, the end of the expected holding period.
We assume that investors are risk-averse so they require a positive premium (higher
return) on risky assets. An investor who is risk-neutral would require no risk premium
and, as a result, would discount the expected future value of an asset at the risk-free rate.
